boardgame.name: The Great War
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

The Great War...is set in a magical world, named Elon, where magic is at the brink of extinction. Steel, steam power and gunpowder are taking over. The technology is comparable with that of the first world war. The same weapons, vehicles and bloody mess. Except there's still some magic in the air.

User summary:

The Great War was an ambitious concept to detail a complete d20 game implementation around a campaign setting based on an alternative-history world named Elon. The project faltered during development, however, and only portions of the setting were completed. The setting comprises a world map, a world history, and some additional/variant rules for d20 to support automobiles and vehicles. For example, the Skills Drive, Pilot, and Sail are added. The most complete development area was on early 1900s fighter airplanes.

The final-state content was made available in HTML. A downloadable version was contemplated but never produced.

boardgame.name: Kumite
boardgame.description:
Two players battle it out in the attempt to knock out their opponent. If you decrease your opponent's health to zero, you win.

Players manage a dojo of skills using Experience Points to build a deck of attack and defense cards that can adapt to an opponent’s evolving strategy.
The linear mat component allows players to control distance to avoid damage and get in range to strike.

Stuns and takedowns break an opponent’s rhythm leaving him/her without enough stamina to pull off brutal combos.

Holds can create an opening for attack and often work in combination with other moves creating another level of strategy.

boardgame.name: Grand Ages: Medieval
boardgame.description:
It is the year 1050 AD. At the beginning of the High Middle Ages development in Europe has seen an unprecedented level of progress and a rapidly growing population spreads across the length and breadth of the continent. New frontiers are explored, settlements founded and vast trading routes established. As the head of one of these small settlements, it falls upon you to lead your people towards greatness.

Explore a vast world, gather resources, encounter other societies and use your trading expertise to expand and make your fortune. Found new cities, progress your nation with inventive technology and protect your trade routes against barbarian attacks until you are powerful enough to begin your conquest over Europe and forge a bold new empire.

Grand Ages: Medieval is a real-time strategy game from Gaming Minds. Lead your people and advance through the decades by utilising construction, research, expansion and conquest in an area extending from Scandinavia and North Africa; to Portugal, the Caucasus and the Middle East. Rise from the humble role of a simple mayor governing a small settlement and rule over all of Europe. Experience an exciting campaign with elaborately designed cut-scenes, play by your own rules in free play or test your skills in multiplayer against up to 8 players!

Features:


Explore a gigantic game world of over 20 million square kilometres, plot strategically where to found important cities and defend your kingdom against foreign powers


*Raise an army and fight your opponents with knights, archers and cavalry

Produce and trade 20 different goods to meet the demands of your citizens and soldiers: such as coal, fruits and pottery
Research and utilise 50 major technological advancements of the Middle Ages: including the three-field crop rotation, the low warp loom or the longbow
Face devastating natural disasters like storms, fires, volcanoes, droughts, earthquakes… or even the Black Death


Source: The Game Website.

boardgame.name: Grey Lotus (Version 1.0)
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Well, its two main points are the fantasy setting that is not based on Tolkien, and the freeform magic system. Grey Lotus doesn't have "elves" or "dwarves" or "halfings" like most fantasy systems, instead blending Celtic lore with other myths, and mixing in some original creations. The magic system is completely open ended, but limited in enough ways that magician characters are on fairly even footing with non-spellcasters. Other appealing characteristics are an epic, detailed fighting system, open-ended advancement, and the fact that its free!

User summary:

The initial edition of Grey Lotus was released in two very minor variations-version 0.99 in June 2002 and Version 1.0 in July 2002, the differences being almost entirely in formatting and minor editing. The HTML version has occasional formatting issues as it was automatically generated.

boardgame.name: Grey Lotus (Version 1.93)
boardgame.description:
User summary:

Grey Lotus Version 1.93 sometimes refers to itself internally as "version 2". This major revision of the rules vastly clarifies the mechanics, standardizes processes, and presents a more consistent game.

Character generation remains complex and lengthy. Each Attribute pair (Endurance/Strength, Dexterity/Reflexes, Intelligence/Perception, Willpower/Wisdom, and Charisma/Manipulation) is given a named Attribute Group (respectively: Body, Ability, Mind, Spirit, Social). Skills retain a statistic of Rating and Dice, with Rating (1-10) representing ability and Dice (2-5) representing the dice pool for the Skill. Resolution involves rolling the dice pool, selecting the highest result, and adding it to the Attribute associates with the Skill and the Skill Rank. Dice "explode" on a roll of 10. The final result is compared to a Difficulty Level. The rules support a "Margin of Success" and "Margin of Failure" mechanic.

boardgame.name: Legacies (Version 2014)
boardgame.description:
From the Introduction:

Legacies is a fantasy role-playing game, focused upon replicating high fantasy and unusual, sometimes strange cultures and creatures.

User summary:

Legacies is a completely overhauled version of the game formerly titled Grey Lotus. The primary design goal was to simplify and streamline the core mechanic to eliminate complexity that was deemed unnecessary through extensive playtesting. Major changes include swapping d10 for d6, limiting the dice pool, and providing for a smoother probability chart of Skill resolution rolls. Also, Attributes and Skills have been simplified. The setting is changed from monotheistic to polytheistic, has a better climate system, and is politically simplified.

Note: Several sections of the 2014 rules are incomplete.

boardgame.name: You Don't Say
boardgame.description:
'You Don't Say' is a word game played over multiple rounds, where players attempt to guess a specific word based on the verbal clues provided.
Players are first divided into 2-4 teams of at least 2 people, who are either the 'Clue Givers' or 'Guessers', which may change between turns.

As the 'guessers' attempt to determine the mystery word, the clue givers are restricted by 3 simple rules:
-Cannot spell all or part of the word
-Cannot use the word itself, in any form
-Cannot use 'rhymes with' or 'sounds like' clues.

Each turn lasts the length of the included timer (about 1 minute) and so multiple word clues may be attempted if teams talk and answer fast.
Teams progress around the board based on the number of correctly guessed words each turn, plus a roll of the random 'bonus die'.

The first team to reach the 'FINISH' space on the gameboard is the winner!

From the Box:
The Talk FAST, guess FASTER game.

Talk about it. Act it out...But DON'T SAY IT!

You Don't Say is the hilarious, high-energy guessing game where fast talkers team with fast guessers to win!

Get your teammates to guess words based on your clues, without saying the words. The more they answer correctly, the father you move on the board.

With six world-encompassing categories and 3000 simple-to-challenging words, YOU DON'T SAY is fast-talking, quick-moving fun for everyone! 500 Cards! 3000 Words!

Don't Go Alone, the first expansion for Pocket Dungeon Quest, adds new concepts to the core gameplay that gives additional strategic choices to the Heroes. It also introduces campaigns and equipment upgrades that carry over through many sessions of play.

Gear is the highlight of the Don't Go Alone expansion. Gear in PDQ is pieces of equipment that the Hero pulls out of the Treasure Pile as a reward for Leveling Up. There are many different types of Gear which add loads of new skills and abilities to the Heroes as they adventure through the dungeon.

Gear is earned by killing Monsters and Leveling Up and finding keys on the Dungeon Floor. Hardcore players can randomize which pieces of Gear they equip. Otherwise you get to choose which combination of Gear best fits with your style of play. Mix and match the Gear for interesting effects and abilities, and most of all, HAVE FUN!

boardgame.name: Chill (3rd Edition)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Every one of us is weak: mere ants against the stalking giants that have brought us to our knees. Even when we work together, the Unknown is bigger than us, better armed, and better prepared for what’s to come. We have no real advantage, and our greatest victories have been nothing but the monsters toying with us before they descend to feast. Our fight is hopeless.

This is how we’re going to win.

—Hayat Nejem, “How to SAVE the World”

The uneasy feeling that creeps up your spine as you walk down a darkened hallway. The way your footsteps echo oddly on a deserted street at night, as though there was someone walking somewhere behind you. The shape you see out of the corner of your eye when you’re home alone.

The Unknown lurks in the dark.

We all know it. Luckily, some of us use that knowledge to fight. The odds may be against us, but we can win.

Investigate the Unknown.

Rescue the Innocent.

Kill the Monsters.

Will you stand with us? Remember — SAVE is on your side.

Chill 3rd Edition is an investigative horror roleplaying game about people who stand up against monsters, hunting down supernatural threats and protecting the world from the Unknown. You don’t have to be a superhero to be a member of SAVE; you just have to stand up and join us.

boardgame.name: Stawka większa niż życie
boardgame.description:
Stawka większa niż życie (More than life at stake) is board game inspired by most popular tv series produced by TVP (Polish television) in 1967. This black and white series is broadcasted almost every year (by different Polish tv channels).

Action takes place during World War II in Poland occupied by Germans. In game one player becomes a member of the Polish resistance and try to execute tasks against occupants.

The second player becomes a member of German forces and tries to stop Polish actions.

Each player controls up to four agents. Each turn player choose a card which decides whose agent first makes his move and what is the amount of action points. This points can be used to moving agents on map and taking special actions like searching for items or evidence of illegal activity. They can try to talk with enemy agents to force them to reveal secret information. German agents may try arrest Poles but polish agents may try to make assassination of gestapo officers. After successful actions, players receive Victory Points.

Both players can play cards to use special effects or to disturb enemy actions.

Every scenario has special win conditions (like finding some items or execute some activities). If this conditions are not achieved, players must compare Victory Points they gathered.

boardgame.name: Alien Dawn Gamemaster Handbook
boardgame.description:
User summary:

The Alien Dawn Gamemaster Handbook is the principle document providing the science fiction genre mechanics for the game system. The document was created about 1991 and released in various formats prior to the 1996 version. The final version of the Gamemaster Handbook was published as a series of fourteen WordPerfect documents in a ZIP archive. Roughly simultaneously, the material was released in a series of ASCII text files. The Gamemaster Handbook provides rules for Aliens (including technology, weapons, and spaceships), tips for campaign management, and methods to use cards (distributed separately) to randomize events. It also includes a bestiary. The bulk of the book, however, is devoted to combat which occurs in phases and is played with scale miniatures. Combat includes everything from archaic weapons to futuristic vehicle combat.

boardgame.name: Daggers
boardgame.description:
Daggers is an asymmetrical abstract board game played on an 8x8 board.

As described by João Pedro Neto on The World of Abstract Board Games:

UPHILL & DOWNHILL - "Downhill" refers to the direction towards the "Low player", and "Uphill" refers to the direction towards the "High player".
DAGGER - Daggers slide along the column or diagonals downhill as far as they like, but only one cell uphill or diagonally uphill. There is no side movement. Daggers can capture any piece along the diagonals (going either uphill or downhill) and can capture Crowns (but not Daggers) along the column.
CROWNS - A Crown can move to any (orthogonal or diagonal) adjacent empty cell. A Crown can also capture any enemy piece on any (orthogonal or diagonal) adjacent cell.
TURN - On each turn, each player moves one of his pieces. The High player moves first.
GOAL - A player wins by capturing an enemy Crown or by moving one of his own Crowns into the opponent's first row.

boardgame.description:
User summary:

The Gamemaster Handbook was published in final format as "Release 5.1". This was provided as sixteen ZIP archives of WordPerfect format files. This same edition of the book was released in RTF and PostScript formats as well as in ASCII text format. Numerous prior editions of the book exist in various formats. A later single ZIP archive gathered all WordPerfect files and two GIF files (intended for full-page printing) of the cover and frontispiece into a single download.

The Gamemaster Handbook was intended to provide a generic, universal framework for gaming in nearly any genre but retains much of the fantasy genre with which it originally was designed.

The handbook includes a section on converting other gaming system characters and statistics into The Guide to Adventure format. It also includes methods for managing campaigns and how to use Cards to randomize events. A variety of special types of damage is considered. Materials also include a Bestiary, an herbal guide, magical equipment, and a notes and rules on siege warfare. The bulk of the manual, however, details the complex combat round and how it proceeds.

boardgame.name: Carbon Copy Politics
boardgame.description:
A strategy card game about well intended people in bitter competition over exactly how to save the planet from climate change...and how to serve their own special interests while doing so.

Take on the role of a special interest group trying to save the world from a changing climate. However, while all the interest groups want to maximize positive impact, they all have different priorities for how to go about it. Are you advocating clean energy, habitat protection, or island nations that might get flooded? Will you pass laws to create subsidies, institute a carbon tax, or maybe attempt an ambitious geo-engineering project? Every method has its own benefits and drawbacks, and you will need strategic planning and political cunning to lead your organization to success.

Mechanics:
Players attempt to pass bills into law, both to have an impact in general and to further their own special interest's goals. However, all players will need to pursue a mixed strategy to succeed -- your special interest does not dictate your strategy. For example, a player might be rewarded for seeing enough geo-engineer projects succeed, regardless of who plays those cards -- so they might play those cards themselves or negotiate for someone else to play them.

Carbon Copy Politics uses a novel "clock" mechanic to track the progress of activities over time. Players play cards onto the clock, which ticks down each turn. Cards that reach the end of the clock resolve, building variable delays into the play of every card. The delay requires players to plan ahead, allow them to set up combos, and creates opportunities for disruption by opponents. For example, bill cards are typically delayed by 3 turns before they are evaluated, so you might play it one turn, play an action to boost public will-for-change the next turn, play a modifier on it the next turn, and then discard cards as the bill resolves to pay the rest of the cost.

Bill cards are rated by their difficulty (cost) and impact (score). Different types of bills offer different ways to pay the cost. Carbon Tax bills get easier to pass as more taxes are passes, while Cap and Trade bills are easier if several are played at the same time by different players.

boardgame.name: Colt Express: Der Zeitreise-Wagen
Colt Express: The Time Travel Car
boardgame.description:
The Time Travel Car can be used with or without the first expansion: Horses & Stagecoach.
The Time Travel Car is placed in front of the Locomotive.
The Time Travel Car is considered as adjacent to the roof and the inside of the Locomotive. So your Bandit can enter it thanks to a Move action or a Horse action if you play using the Horses and Stagecoach expansion.

Several Bandits can go in the Time Travel Car at the same time, but in order to trigger the action, your Bandit has to be alone in it at the end of a round (after applying the event, if the current round has one).
If this condition is met, all of the other players close their eyes. In the meantime, you must take your Bandit pawn and hide it below the Locomotive; below one of the Cars; or below the Stagecoach (if you are playing with the expansion). Then, the next Schemin’ phase is played and none of the other players know where your Bandit is. The Bandit’s location is disclosed at the beginning of the Stealin’ phase and the pawn is placed inside the Car where it was hiding. Then all of the actions are resolved.
At the end of the game, after the event is resolved, if one Bandit is alone inside the Time Travel Car, the player receives $500 and all of the loot that may be contained inside.

The players begin on the Start square, and the Twinkles playing piece starts several squares ahead. Players draw cards that have colors on them and move to the next square with that color on the board. Players must draw a card for Twinkles and move him on his turn, as well. Players cannot pass Twinkles, even if that means they cannot move. Certain squares award the players stars, and others take stars away (if they have any). When Twinkles finally makes it to the Star Factory, the game is over. The player who has the most stars, wins.

[b]All prices are inclusive of UK and EU VAT, but do not include shipping costs.[/b]
[size=14][b]Flat Rate Shipping:[/b][/size] The shipping cost is the same regardless of the number of items ordered: 2 Euros within Germany. 3 Euros to Albania, Australia, Belarus, Brazil, Canada, China, Faroe Islands, Greenland, Iceland, Ireland, Indonesia, Israel, Japan, Liechtenstein, Malaysia, New Zealand, Norway, Russia, Singapore, South Korea, Switzerland, Taiwan, Thailand, Turkey, and the USA. 4 Euros to Austria, Belgium, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Czech Republic, Cyprus, Estonia, Finland, France, Greece, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxemburg, Macedonia, Malta, Moldavia, Monaco, Montenegro, Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Ukraine, United Kingdom, and Vietnam. 5 Euros to Bulgaria, Croatia, Denmark, Hungary, Romania, and Sweden. 6 Euros to all other countries.
NOTE: The shipping rates for deliveries outside of the EU and UK have been discounted to make up for the fact that no VAT is paid for sales outside of the EU and UK. However, there may be import taxes for deliveries outside of the EU and UK, and the buyer is responsible paying these.
[size=14][b]Payment Options:[/b][/size]
[size=12][b]Paypal:[/b][/size] No fee is charged to you, if you pay using Paypal. But Paypal does not change currency at the fair market rate. So you will lose 3% or more of your money, if you are converting to Euros.
[size=12][b]IBAN Bank Transfer:[/b][/size] Payment by bank transfer is possible using an IBAN compatible account. [b]There is a 3% discount if you pay using IBAN Bank Transfer[/b] (i.e., your total payment due is 3% less).
[size=12][b]Wise:[/b][/size] There is a 3% discount if you pay using Wise (i.e., your total payment due is 3% less). The company does currency conversion at the fair market rate, and charges the sender a fee of about 0.5% of the amount of money sent.
[size=12][b]Revolut:[/b][/size] There is a 3% discount if you pay using Revolut (i.e., your total payment due is 3% less). The company does currency conversion at the fair market rate, and there are no fees to send money.
[size=12][b]Interac e-transfer:[/b][/size] If you have a Canadian bank account (like me), then you can pay by Interac e-transfer. boardgame.name: Chill Quickstart: Good Fences Make Good Neighbors
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Reuben Hall disppeared from his parents' home last night. He out there somewhere, the captive of a creature of the Unknown. The police are looking for him diligently, but they don't know what they're looking for or the nature of what they're facing - but you do. You're members of the Eternal Society of the Silver Way, dedicated to protecting others from the Unknown.

You have very little time, though. Will you stand with us? Remember — SAVE is on your side.

Chill 3rd Edition is an investigative horror roleplaying game about people who stand up against monsters, hunting down supernatural threats and protecting the world from the Unknown. You don’t have to be a superhero to be a member of SAVE; you just have to stand up and join us.

Good Fences Make Good Neighbors is a free scenario for Chill 3rd Edition. It includes all the rules you need to play it, and comes with five pre-generated characters. The scenario plays in two to four hours, depending on your group, and serves as an introduction into the game system and setting of Chill 3rd Edition.

boardgame.name: Generalship: from the 4th century B.C. to the 19th century
boardgame.description:
Generalship is a compact strategy game and the players can experience the history of Europe.

You will compete using 49 highly famed generals in Europe from the 4th century B.C. to the 19th century. You choose a nation to rule: Austria, Byzantium, England, or France, and then appoint a general from the 49 ones available as your commander. Using this, you will run your nation internally by accumulating political power, increasing production and population, and developing technologies. You will handle your external politics by raising armies and managing alliance relationships.
 
While shaping history with other players, based on your efficient use of actions, the abilities of your commander, and a little bit of luck, you will be able to win by earning more victory points than your competitors. Specifically, players can earn victory points by winning battles or developing new technologies.

boardgame.description:
The Sons of Ragnarok are a notorious outlaw biker gang, that could very nearly have become Acolytes of Sin themselves. However, their total rejection for following orders made any approach to try and conscript them to aid the sins result in a very dead servant of sin. This biker gang is obsessed with Viking mythology, with members assuming nicknames in reference to the Norse Gods. The realization that the Apocalypse (or Ragnarok, as they prefer to call it) was upon them stirred the gang into a battle frenzy! However, their contempt for authority also means they would never agree to join FAITH. Though that doesn't stop them from carrying on the fight against the Others on their own terms!

The Sons of Ragnarok Expansion box contains a full team of 7 heroes, including a Leader, 2 Fixers, 2 Snipers, and 2 Bruisers. These rebels tend to operate outside of FAITH, but they can be mixed and matched with any FAITH team as your group may choose. This team follows the same rules as any FAITH group, though they were designed with special synergy among themselves.

boardgame.name: Sapotagem
boardgame.description: Sapotagem is a card game using trick-taking with set collection. In each trick, players have two options: play a card or pass. The winner of that trick is the player who played the highest card of color to be followed or the Trump color, if it has been played. The color of the trump of each round is determined by a list of cards in the middle of the table placed in the setup. The winner of each trick takes all the cards played, besides the card that determines the trump of the round, and places them in rows in his player area, separated by existing symbols. At the end of the game, each player gets victory points for each type of symbol that has, depending on the amount. Up to 3 symbols of a particular type, the score is positive. 4 to 6 symbols of the same type the score is negative. 7 or 8 symbols of the same type score is again positive. All cards 13 are time bombs, worth negative points, except that the same player has captured all 4! The winner has the most victory points!

The Others: La Gourmandise
The Others: Obżarstwo
The Others: Völlerei
boardgame.description:
The Gluttony Expansion box comes with Avatar, Controller, 6 Abominations, Sin board and 12 sin cards.

The Others: 7 Sins is a horror board game for 2 to 5 players. One player controls one of the 7 Deadly Sins, employing monstrous incarnations of these corruptive forces in an attempt to consume the world and bring about the apocalypse. The rest of the players cooperate as heroes of the F.A.I.T.H. organization who will attempt to fight back the invasion!

The Sins player, on the other hand, has access to the different monsters of each Sin, including Abominations, a Controller, and the terrifying Avatar of Sin! These monsters can attempt to destroy the heroes, or simply hinder their progress on their missions.

Each Sin provides the Sins Player with a different deck of Sins cards that can be played at different times to surprise players with different effects, often tied to the strategy of each Sin. Yes, because each Sin taints the game with an overarching mechanic that is always in effect.

boardgame.name: Das Hinauswerfer-Spiel
boardgame.description:
Each player has a set of 3 pawns that start on the starting spaces of his color. The goal is to move the pawns around the board along the spiral to the "home" section. Movement is controlled by a die. All players move around the same board, so they may capture each other's pawns. Captured pawns are returned to their player's starting place and must start their journey over. The winner is the first player to move all pawns "home".

On the back of the game board is the game Nine Men's Morris (Mühle).

boardgame.name: Squish
boardgame.description:
Squish is a fun, family friendly, dexterity game for 1 to 6 players in which you drop player order cards (also referred to as boot cards) in an attempt to squish bug cards that are on the ground. You try to be the player with 10+ points at the end of a round. The bug cards are thrown into the air at the beginning of the game and fall where they may. After, you are ready to get Squishing! You go in number order according to your player order cards. You drop your player order cards from shoulder height, number side up, in an attempt to completely cover a bug. Bugs range in size and value. The bigger the bug, the more points it is worth. Beware though, because if your player order card lands boot side up someone can cover your number and take one of your squished bugs from you. You squish the bug and your friend steps on your toes and takes it from you. This could turn a win into a loss or a loss into a win. Getting 10 points is easy, keeping them is tough. Some dropping techniques can make it so that your card is boot side down and keeps you safe from anyone's nefarious plans of stepping on your toes.

A variant for younger crowds makes the game a bit easier by the requirement to cover a bug goes from, covering the entire bug, to covering just the head or body.

Squish: The Dexterity Card Game of Bug Squishery is a fun and easy game for kids of all ages and plays in only 30 minutes.

boardgame.name: Harlequinade: Ideal World (Version 3)
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

This game has been officially certified ‘politically incorrect’. Harlequinade, with its cynical, disrespectful world view has been known to induce fatal moral indignation in people who have had their sense of humour surgically removed and replaced by a corncob. If you are a po-faced moral nazi, or mentally ill, please read no further for your own peace of mind.

User summary:

In Harlequinade, players play Victims (characters) who proceed through a Nightmare (adventure) run by The Harlequin (GM). The Harlequin is also sometimes called "You Callous Bastard". All Nightmares are set in the Ideal World (the game world).

Victims have eight Primary Attributes (Strength, Dexterity, Agility, Health, Willpower, Presence, Beauty, and Alertness). Each Primary Attribute has a numerical Rating of 2-6. Victims also have Combat Attributes with Ratings derived from Primary Attributes. Victims select an Archetype (class): Nobody (the default), Soldier, Thug, Thief, Fatboy, Lunatic, Cultist, or Gentleman of the Night. Victims then generate money to buy Props (equipment).

Actions are either Resisted or Unresisted, each using a different mechanism. For Resisted Actions the opponents compare base Attribute plus Difficulty Modifier plus 2d6--the highest score wins. For Unresisted Actions the Victim adds Base Attribute and Difficulty Modifier and subtracts 2d6, attempting a result less than zero for success.

boardgame.name: Harlequinade (Version 5)
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

You don't want any trouble, but those bastards just keep coming. They stand too close. They smile, but you know how much they hate you. They push you into doing things. The other queue moves faster. They drive too close. They cheat at cards. They whisper about you in the darkness. They move too fast... Wagh, it's out of control...

User summary:

In Harlequinade, players control a Victim (character) that travels through a Nightmare (scenario) created by The Harlequin (GM). The Harlequin is also called "You Callous Bastard". All Nightmares transpire in the Ideal World (game world).

Victims have eight Primary Attributes (Strength, Dexterity, Agility, Health, Willpower, Presence, Beauty, and Alertness) with a numeric Rating from 2-12. Victims also have Combat Attributes with Ratings derived from Primary Attribute Ratings. Victims then select an Archetype (class) from: Nobody (default), Soldier, Thug, Thief, Fatboy, Lunatic, Cultist, Cripple, or Gentleman of the Night. Victims then generate money to buy Props (equipment).

Actions are either Resisted or Unresisted. In Resisted Actions, each opponent adds a Difficulty Modifier to their base Attribute and then adds 2d6. The opponent with the highest result wins. Unresisted Actions use a different mechanism of adding a Difficulty Modifier to the actor's base Attribute and then subtracting 2d6, with a result less than zero indicating success. However, a roll of double 1s is always success and a roll of double 6s is always failure.

boardgame.name: JumPico
boardgame.description:
User Summary:
This is a competitive Sugoroku (Japanese type of Parcheesi) game in which players move 4 of their own pieces from their side to their opponent's side. JumPico is characterized by the fact that players advance their pieces while blocking the movement of their opponent's pieces, as in Backgammon. The first player to move 4 of his pieces to his opponent's side wins the game. Passing is prohibited, so a player with no legal moves automatically loses. Blank pieces can always be used with no risk as they always move one space and are thus key to creating a winning strategy.

Publisher's summary:
４個の持ち駒を自陣から敵陣まで移動させる対戦型すごろくゲームです。
バックギャモンのように自分の駒で敵の移動を妨害しながら交差して駒を進
めるのが特徴です。駒の数字によって移動できるマス数が決まっています。
早く４個の駒を相手陣地まで移動させれば勝ちですが、パスは禁止なので合
法手が無ければ負けになります。
無地駒は必ず１マス進めるので、これを安全パイに使いながら移動の戦術を
組み立てます。

boardgame.name: Super 11
boardgame.description:
The Ultimate Football Strategy Game! The game is a dice and card, turn based game. The object of the game is to score more goals than your opponent in a set amount of time, or to be the first to score a pre-determind number of goals.

Players roll the dice, and move their playing pieces around the board, trying to get close enough to their opponents goal to take a shot. When a player lands with the ball on one of the Super 11 squares in their opponents half, they play an attacking card. These bonus cards can give them an advantage over their opponent through a shot at goal, yellow or red card, or a chance to roll again.

The game ends either after an agreed period of time, or once a player has scored the pre-agreed number of goals.

boardgame.name: HARPE Lite
boardgame.description:
HARPE lite
HARPE: The Hugely Adaptable (Action/Anime) Role-Playing Engine
LITE: "Lacking in Technically Encumbered" Game-Mechanics

HARPE lite is a "stripped" version of HARPE, to provide quick play access to the game. Most of the rules--and all of the special-situation rules--have been removed.

Characters follow a Template (Common, Daring, Dramatic, Heroic, Super-Heroic) to gain 0-4 Abilities and 0-4 Deeds. These are narrative tags created by the player, with examples being things like: Artistic Ability, Combat Ability, Linguistics Ability, Social Ability, Stealth, Survival, and Vehicle Operations. Deeds indicate how often a character may utilize non-common Abilities before recovery periods (which vary), with values ranging from 1-7. Different levels of Abilities have different dice pools, running from 1d6 to 4d6+4. When an opposed action is resolved it causes the loser to accumulate "Points of Defeat" which are vaguely like abstracted hit points in other systems. Points of Defeat regenerate during recovery periods. Actions are resolved by rolling the dice pool and looking for successes in the results, the number of successes determining the nature of the outcome.
boardgame.rpg: HARPE: The Hugely Adaptable (Action/Anime) Role-Playing Engine

boardgame.name: HARPE (Version 3.0)
boardgame.description:
HARPE: The Hugely Adaptable (Action/Anime) Role-Playing Engine

Characters are built following a Template (Common, Daring, Dramatic, Heroic, Super-Heroic) to gain 0-4 Abilities and 0-4 Deeds. These are narrative tags created by the player, with examples being things like: Artistic Ability, Combat Ability, Linguistics Ability, Social Ability, Stealth, Survival, and Vehicle Operations. Deeds indicate how often a character may utilize non-common Abilities before recovery periods (which vary), with values ranging from 1-7.

Different levels of Abilities have different dice pools, running from 1d6 to 4d6+4. When an opposed action is resolved it causes the loser to accumulate "Points of Defeat" which are vaguely like abstracted hit points in other systems. Points of Defeat regenerate during recovery periods. Actions are resolved by rolling the dice pool and looking for successes in the results, the number of successes determining the nature of the outcome.

Combat works in a similar way but offers various special situations. Combat supports initiative, surprise, ambush, and so forth. However, the combat round remains an abstracted series of events and the goal of the mechanics are to minimize the time spent rolling dice in combat in favor of developing an exciting narrative action.

boardgame.name: A Fairy Tale Fantasy
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

A Fairy Tale Fantasy covers the stereotypical Knights in Shining Armor, Dashing Rogues, Mysterious Magicians and other such fabled tellings of children's Fairy Tale Books and Legends (no matter which race they come from). A Fairy Tale Fantasy draws upon all that is a child's imagination, simplicity, and innocence and focuses it into a genre in which truly anything can happen. We focus on childhood imagination because in Fairy Tales it lets anything happen without having to worry too much about explaining why. Childhood simplicity in Fairy Tales breaks the complications and restrictions we adults cause ourselves with complex rules and grammar. And, childhood innocence in Fairy Tales keeps them revolving around being a better person, making the right decisions, helping others, and learning morals.

boardgame.name: Ego
boardgame.description:
From the Introduction:

Ego is a game that you play before you play your game. It is a Role Playing Game (RPG) that you play before, or rather as part of Character Generation for the RPG campaign you are about to start. At the end of an Ego session (or perhaps multiple sessions) you will have very unique character to play in your new campaign.

You are an intelligent item

In Ego the players take on the role of intelligent items. Intelligent items that have already been found by a group of characters. I'm sure everyone who has played a traditional RPG has run across an intelligent item at one time. They are usually amazing and very powerful magic gear that characters find. A big part of the magic item trope is that these items have a will of their own and will often exert that will and try to control a character.

Ego takes this trope and turns it upside down. In Ego, instead of playing a character who found an intelligent item, you are playing that item that has been found by a character.

boardgame.name: HARPE Jaded
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

There comes a few times in many a well-seasoned role-player's life when they get tired of all the serious RPG's out there trying to be the ultimate definitive guide to complete role-playing satisfaction. And thus, they move on to satirical or humorous RPG's that take a tongue-in-cheek approach to it all. But, even then, the well-seasoned role-player will still find themselves frayed at how an otherwise light-hearted game can still get bogged down by rules and garbage dictating how stupid, annoying, outlandish or otherwise tongue-in-cheek you can be within their stupid, annoying, outlandish or otherwise tongue-in-cheek game.

User summary:

HARPE Jaded attempts to provide a fresh, entertaining, and rules-light game for experienced role-players (for gamers who are "jaded"). The players play a "Player" who in turn plays a "Character". The meta-game can be run with whatever rules seem appropriate, but in addition to playing the (presumably super-cool) meta-Character at one-remove, the player also has to play their "Player" who is assumed to be "the whiny, bitchy" type who likes to play games instead of have a real social life.

boardgame.name: The Sinister Stone of Sakkara
boardgame.description:
(from the back of the book)

Over a millennium ago, when the borderlands were in the dark grip of the Zaharan Empire, the empire’s sorcerer-priests erected a profane temple to house the terrible artifact known as the Stone of Sakkara. Using the Stone, the sorcerer-priests could birth monsters and abominations with frightening ease and magically command the loyalty of chaotic creatures. The Stone brought its evil masters great power throughout the fell empire.

In the centuries since the fall of Zahar, the Stone has lain dormant and forgotten. Now it has awakened, and warbands of beastmen have begun to gather sacrifices to power the Stone’s birthing pools again. Local farms and hamlets have been sacked and pillaged, and entire families have gone missing. The local legate has too few men to even patrol the border; he has none at all to hunt down the source of the evil. Adventurers are needed…

AX1: The Sinister Stone of Sakkara is a ready-to-play adventure presented for use with Adventurer Conqueror King System™ and other d20-based fantasy role-playing games. AX1 includes a two-level dungeon filled with chthonic horror along with a friendly stronghold from which your adventurers can explore the region. The Sinister Stone of Sakkara is the perfect introductory adventure for a campaign starting in ACKS’s official setting but easy to adapt to your campaign setting of choice. Begin your rise from adventurer to king today!

boardgame.name: Tiny Token Toss
boardgame.description:
Tiny Token Toss

Tiny Token Toss is an 18-card - 1 or 2-player Dexterity chit tossing game. "I may be starting a trend with these games!"

It uses the same chit tossing mechanic from castle under siege but in a nice and simple point scoring game.

Tiny Token Toss uses 6 cards in front of each player "a seventh card can be added to the back row" with each card having a circle with point values in it. Each player takes turns tossing chits at the cards to try and obtain the most points or trying to knock their opponents chits off the cards.

The rules are simple and the game is a light filler style game! I calling this new innovative style of game "The chit toss game"! LOL

14 cards make up the scoring cards.
2 cards represent each player's toss card.
2 cards represent the bean bags.

If you think of the beach bean bag tossing game, that's this game in a nut shell!

boardgame.name: Castle under Siege
boardgame.description:
CASTLE UNDER SIEGE

Castle under Siege is an 18-card - 1 or 2-player Dexterity Medieval Castle Siege game.

Player-1 controls the Catapult and tries to loft "boulder, fireball, and disease" towards a castle. You use one of the cards as an actual catapult; tossing ammunition at the castle.

Player-2 maintains the castle and must use his forces to put out fires, repair boulder damage, and take card of the injured soldiers. To do this you must move around the castle trying to reach and resolve each situation before it gets out of control. All the while trying to stay alive because if a boulder lands in an area where your forces are they are either killed or injured.

You have a limited supply of ammunition and once you run out the game is over. You tally your score to see if you breached the castle wall or tower. Or see how many forces you were able to kill!

The player of the castle wins by preventing a wall or tower breach and trying to save as many soldiers as possible.

boardgame.name: Mythomakya
boardgame.description:
Mythomakya is a card game about greek mythology designed by Luca Feliciani and illustrated by Mirka Andolfo.

In the box, You'll find 110 cards that allow you to play two different games based on a similar game-play.

The aim of the game is to gain more golden apples than your opponents. When the first player plays a card, the opponents have to play a card of the same color. The one with the highest strenght, wins and puts all the cards in his treasure.
If a player cannot play the same color, he has to play another color and will always lose unless the color played is the moira, the dominant color choosen at the beginning of the game by one of the players.

In the version “Triumph of Heroes” you’ll use heroes as Hector, Aeneas, Jason and Perseus to conquer more golden apples than your opponents. Cards are placed in front of the players in ten 3-card stacks. Only the first card of each stack is visible. When it's played, the card below can be revealed.

In the version “God’s Challenge” deities from the Olympus will join the fight, such as titans, muses and orrible monsters with particular skills. In this version, indeed, each player can activate abilities of 30 special cards by eliminating from the treasure a number of golden apples. These abilities can change the game, since their effects are very strong.
Moreover, each player has some divinity cards in his hand. As per the abilities, a player has to eliminate golden apples from the treasure to play the divinity cards.
In this version, all the cards are displayed but only the first one of each stack is playable.

boardgame.name: Cthulhu Grundregelwerk
boardgame.description:
(Translated from the back of the book)
Cthulhu - the horror role-playing game on the motives of the author Howard Phillips Lovecraft, probably the most influential and important author of the 20th century in the field of horror fiction. Here his world comes alive.
Cthulhu - Das Grundregelwerk (The basic rules) is the
indispensable tools for the game master to immerse a group of players in the world of H.P. Lovecraft. Here you will find all the necessary rules and information about the terrible Cthulhu Mythos, his forgotten tomes, ghastly creatures and powerful gods, spells and magical rituals. In addition to a guide on how the GM successfully masters cthuloid gaming evenings, two adventure ready for entry into the cthuloid horror are contained. The rulebook is now available in the new, improved edition 7; no further rulebooks are required.

boardgame.name: Names of the Disloyal
boardgame.description:
In Russia, everyone is responsible to the Motherland to ensure every citizens is a good comrade.

In Names of the Disloyal, you must turn in the names of those who are striving to disrupt the harmony among the people. Roll dice to gather the letters needed to discover the dissidents, use the help of your comrade workers, and find those rumored to be disloyal.

On your turn, you will roll dice, claim cards to your hand and then make names with those cards. The first player to a set number of names triggers the end game.

Game Contents:
162 Letter Cards (Letters of the Revolution)
36 Name Cards (Find the Disloyal)
8 Multi Letter Cards (Workers Unite)
7 Dice each in 4 different colors
12 Scoring Tiles
1 Scorepad

boardgame.name: Cthulhu Investigatoren-Kompendium
boardgame.description:
(translated from the back of the book)
Long before the rise of humanity the Great Old Ones ruled the earth. The traces of their cyclopean cities are still on outlying islands, buried in the desert sand and seen the polar ice. Once they came from the stars to our world. Now they sleep, some far below the earth's surface or in the sea. When the stars are right, they will rise up and walk the earth again.

The horror RPG CTHULHU is based on the works of the writer Howard Phillips Lovecraft. His greatest and most enduring creation became known as the Cthulhu Mythos. Here ordinary people face the terrible and strange forces of the unknown.

Can you assert yourself against the nameless horror?

For all those who take on the roles of investigators and oppose the terrible Cthulhu Mythos, the investigators compendium provides in particular:

Advanced rules for character creation

numerous professional and skills descriptions

a variety of organizations, which your Investigator could belong to

practical tips for a living as Investigator

Detailed information about the 1920s

Hints and tips on how one can get the most fun out of CTHULHU

Equipment and weapons descriptions.

The useful handbook to Edition 7!

boardgame.name: Rise of the Guardians: The Video Game
boardgame.description:
Let your imagination soar in Rise of the Guardians: The Video Game. Play as one of the classic childhood legends, including North, Tooth, Bunnymund, Sandman, and Jack Frost. In this action-packed adventure game, each Guardian has their own set of upgradable and extraordinary abilities that will help you take on the evil spirit Pitch and his infectious nightmares. Along the way, you will unlock new powers and spellbinding special moves that will increase your character's strength and skills throughout the game, plus you can unleash cool team attacks with your fellow heroes. With drop-in-and-out multiplayer action supporting up to four players on consoles, you and your team of Guardians will work together to protect the hopes, beliefs and imaginations of children all over the world!

Join Forces with Your Favorite Characters From the Film – Play as one of the classic childhood legends from DreamWorks Animation's upcoming feature film, Rise of the Guardians, including: North, Tooth, Bunnymund, Sandman, and Jack Frost.

Battle Pitch in an Epic Adventure – Take on Pitch and his evil nightmares in a deep and intuitive adventure combat game that includes new original enemies designed specifically for each Guardian's realm.

Unique Abilities and Upgrades – Unlock power-ups such as weapon upgrades for your character. Plus, earn unique new abilities including special combat moves like a snowball attack, summoning a swarm of miniature tooth fairies, and more!

Explore Legendary Guardian Realms – Experience the imaginative worlds from Rise of the Guardians, including; Tooth's Palace, North's Workshop, Bunnymund's Warren, and many more.

Team up in Multiplayer – Swap between any of the characters in drop-in-and-out four-player squad based multiplayer action on consoles.

boardgame.name: Unitar
boardgame.description:
Unitar is a simultanuous-choice 8 round 3 person strategy poker and, hopefully, the Arabic game.

Goal
You win Unitar by dominating the field with your color, in other words the game color with the highest number of frames on the playing field wins.

Strategy
Each turn, every player selects one block of stones that will be moved or rotated. By doing so, blocks may start to overlap. When blocks overlap, actions can be selected to eliminate the overlapping pieces, or to unify the two blocks, which means that the squares they occupy are divided amongst the two colors.

Poker
You have to guess your opponent's intended moves, because your own intended move will only be performed if it shares two characteristics with the other player's moves.

boardgame.name: Rise of Champions
boardgame.description:
The first 140-card expansion for the Ophidian 2350 CCG, Rise of Champions continues the storyline for Ophidian and introduces new gladiators, additional level cards for some gladiators from the original set, new effects, new card types, and more! This series is offered in 30-count booster displays.

Unfortunately a printed expansion never got green light as the publisher Fleer/Skybox International has announced that '...based on current market conditions,' it is canceling its Rise of Champions booster for the Ophidian 2350 CCG.

In making the announcement, Fleer Senior VP Sales and Marketing Lloyd Pawlak noted Fleer's inability to get retailer support as the determining factor in ending new release support for the game. 'The strong core support of our players and volunteers and the only 5 star gameplay rating for CCGs in Scrye this year... was not enough to convince more retailers to carry and support the game,' he said.

Fleer Director of Gaming Initiatives David Chase told ICv2 that not all support for the game is ending.'We are still soliciting sales for Ophidian 2350,' he said.'Ophidian still runs Organized Play along with supporting various conventions with product and tournament support.'

And due to the Fan support, Ophidian Inc, the creators/designers of the game, managed to release the expansion as a print and play version.

boardgame.name: Hazon
boardgame.description:
User summary:

Hazon was published in early 1988 as a public post in ASCII text format.

Characters have six Abilities (Strength, Dexterity, Constitution, Intelligence, Wisdom, and Will Power) with Scores. Scores are distributed form a point pool of d100 + 360 by player fiat. All non-human races have an Ability Score cap on two to four Abilities, ranging from 90-120 (70 is average). Ability Scores are used on a single table that determines an Ability Bonus for every Ability, ranging from -15 to +40 (0 is average). Hit Points are determined by a formula with an added 3d10 (23 is average). Characters also select Skills which improve through Training or Experience.

Non-trivial actions are resolved by comparing a d100 roll added to Ability Bonus added to Skill Bonus to a Difficulty determined by the GM. Combat is handled as "a glorified performance roll" with additional modifiers. If successful, a hit's damage is determined from how much the modified roll exceeded the Difficulty. Criticals and fumbles are supported.

boardgame.name: Ophidian Legends (fan expansion for Ophidian 2350)
boardgame.description:
The Ophidian Legends is a 25-card expansion special mini-set and has as the main theme the Legendary Ophidian League Gladiators. And there’s more, much more as we also showcase in a 5 cards subset focusing the most brutal war that happened in the Ophidian Universe, the Demon Wars!!!

And as if that is not enough the set also brings back the Reindeer's Minions that were seen last year in the Holiday 2004 set, after all we’re on Christmas Season, and although we don’t have the return of Arkon Klaus, this set also includes a 5 cards subset with many cards for him (or any other Gladiator) to use.

The expansion also features two brand new mechanisms:

Legendary Cards

This Set include Gladiators, Minions and Pumps with a keyword that indicate that they are Legendary Characters, this keyword is currently seen in two Gladiators cards Arkon Klaus (from Holiday 2004 set) & Pestilence (from WOF set). The Legendary Characters are Ophidian League Gladiators, they may be included in any Team, and they act like any regular Gladiator. When a Legendary Gladiator is destroyed he is placed in the Funeral Pyre, and your opponent’s gains the double of the VP of the Legendary Gladiator. The Legendary cards are also unique cards, and even though they don’t have the keyword written on them, they automatically count as unique cards.

Minions that act like Gladiator Cards

This Set include Minions with the following text “CARD NAME counts as a XVP {DISCIPLINE}{DISCIPLINE} Gladiator”. Currently only one Minion cards has this Mechanism, Doombringer (from The OutWorlds Revelations set). The Minion can use Pumps that apply for the stated Disciplines and VP, but for all the purposes the card is still a Minion card. It also mean that when the Minion is destroyed he also is Placed in the Funeral Pyre alongside the Gladiators cards, and as that the
opponent will gain the VP mentioned on the Minion card. If the Minion card has also the Legend keyword, the VP that the opponent will gain when the minion is destroyed is determinate by the Legendary Cards Mechanism.

boardgame.name: HYPeR - Module A: Basic Rules
boardgame.description:
User summary:

HYPeR was intended to be a generic, universal role-playing system that would support magic, super powers, psionics, and high technology. The author contemplated eight modules but produced only Module A: Basic Rules. Module A was accompanied by a Character Sheet and a Damage Log. Module A provides sufficient basic rules to play in any genre as long as the various genre-specific elements are provided by the user. The rules follow a rigorous format.

All tasks are attempted against a Difficult Level ranging from -30 to 100 (15 is an "average task"); the game is played at a Technical Level ranging from 0 to 20 (11 is "modern"). These are standard for the entire game.

Character creation begins with a concept and demographics, then the selection of a Profession (e.g., class) and the purhcase of Attributes, of which there are ten, from a points pool. The Awareness Attribute is sub-divided into the five senses with individual scores in each. Characters also have thirty-three derived attributes, most of which related to combat. A character's Profession grants access to Skills which have several different types of scores, the basic performance level is purchased from a point pool. Numerous Skills relate to combat. Combat is quite complex and supports a wide range of options and supports numerous special situations.

boardgame.name: Hive Colony (fan expansion for Hive)
boardgame.description:
Posted with permission of John Yianni, designer of Hive.


Hive Colony is a collection of unofficial expansions for Hive designed by Stephen Taylor. It includes Hive: Original, Venom, Swarm, Predators, Guardians and Honeycombo.

Hive: Venom – Includes all the original pieces in addition to some new creatures on the reverse sides. You must decide which face up to place the pieces depending on the current state of the board and your future plans. You can flip the pieces but this will cost you a tempo. The new pieces are designed not to over power the Originals be rather to compliment them and present the player with more strategic choices.

Hive: Swarm – A mode of play which adds in a little bit of randomness to Hive and challenges the player to make the best use of the hand they are dealt. It can be played with Hive Original or any of the expansions and even allows you to place your opponent's pieces!

Hive: Predators – Introduces some powerful pieces with killer moves which can permanently remove an opponent's creatures from the Hive. It also introduces the alternative victory condition of removing your opponent's Queen Bee which encourages even more interesting ways to play and the greater possibility to come back from a losing position.

Hive: Guardians – Dominate the top of the Hive with these high flying creatures. You now have to fully surround the Queen Bee so even the top must be covered to win. They can also be very useful in neutralising some of the new expansions when playing with all the expansions together.

Hive: Honeycombo – This piece is shared by both players which allows you sacrifice your current turn in order to then play two moves in your next turn. This opens up many new possibilities such as being able to place and move a piece without it getting pinned, or moving two pieces in to surround the Queen without your opponent being able to move one away with the Pillbug.

Please see attached files for the rules and print and play stickers.

From the introduction:

Welcome to the dawn of the 22nd Century. Democracy has failed, having long since been replaced by a corporate mentality. Americorp and Eurocorp, on the verge of their second war over natural resources, are no longer the powers they once were. Globalization has led to a dispersal of resources and power. Money is the ultimate equalizer, and the ultimate goal; so much so that the value of the individual citizen has been all but erased.

There are no names now. There are only faces that pass each other by, like whispers on a foggy night. You are only what they have in their file, a value hastily scribbled in a column in a long-forgotten database, a mere calculation. You don't have feelings. You don't have any worth other than what you can do for them. You are not a person. You aren't even a character. You are an object. A thing. You are an icon.

boardgame.name: Imaginality
boardgame.description:
User summary:

Imaginality is intended to be a generic, universal system that can be used in any genre. The core rules detail a method of card handling that is used to resolve all actions (opposed or unopposed) and combat. Every rule besides the Card rules is considered optional.

The card game has a deck and a discard pile for played cards. Characters start the adventure with seven cards. Cards in standard rank, ace high, are scored 2 through 15. A joker, when played, results in two cards drawn from the deck and summed to provide a score--then all three cards are discarded; e.g., results may be really good or really bad. The GM also has a hand for NPCs. Resolution first establishes a difficulty and then cards of those involved are played face down and revealed simultaneously. The action may require another card draw.

Imaginality uses the hackneyed concept that characters are intended to be "yourself", or, the player. From this basis Attributes can be defined and advanced through game experience, represented by the gaining and spending of Character Points.

boardgame.name: The Little Big Game of Lexis Hold'em
boardgame.description:
The Little Big Game of Lexis Hold'em transforms Texan Hold'em into a word game. Instead of forming straights, flushes or pairs, players spell words. The game ends when only one player has chips remaining. That person is the winner.

Each player receives an equal number of betting chips. The dealer deals 2 "hole" cards to each player and 5 "community" cards face down. Players must place a chip into the pot to play in the hand.

The Pre-Flop (Round One): After looking at their own cards, the players can check or bet. The following players can call (equal the last bet placed in the pot), raise (increase the last bet placed in the pot), or fold (sit out the hand and lose all bets placed so far).

The Flop (Round Two): The dealer turns over the first 3 "community" cards.

The Turn Card (Round Three): The dealer turns over the 4th "community" card.

The River (Round Four): The dealer turns over the last "community" card.

After each round players use their own cards and the community cards to form a word and a round of betting occurs. After the last round players secretly write down their words before betting.

The Showdown: After all betting is done, players who have not folded show their cards. The player that forms the word worth the most points takes all the chips in the pot.

boardgame.name: Biff Baff
boardgame.description:
Biff Baff is the crazy Drumming-Game which will unleash your inner musician. With 13 fun and yet challenging gaming options each player can test his or her sense of rhythm. Just let loose and beat the drums along with up to three other players while discovering your own musical potential. You don’t even require a conductor; the integrated rotary disk will lead you through the different rhythm patterns which you can choose for yourself. Different symbols for the disk ensure diversified rhythms and suspense for your games. The winner of Biff Baff will be the one who can keep the beat going the longest and is thus crowned the new drumming king. The whole game is made of wood which ensures stability and persistency. Playing the game will improve your sense of rhythm and helps building social skills for children starting at the age of three.

Game Explanation.
The gaming board is divided into four colored sections which gives up to four players the opportunity to drum at the same time. Every section is imprinted with one blue and two red hand symbols which mark the two sounds (bass, snare). Additionally there is a white arrow which points towards the middle to the rotary disk. This disk fulfills the position of the conductor during the game. Up to six magnets can be placed on the disk which symbolize different activities like playing the bass drum or snapping one’s fingers. To start the game one spins the disk once it stops the arrow points to the action which has to be performed.

Biff Baff: Assisting development without anxiety but lots of fun! The game offers over ten types playing options depending on the age of the child which improve the following aspects:

- The importance of community and the role of the individual
- A sense of rhythm and reaction time
- Sharpening the senses: Auditory and visual perception
- eye-hand coordination, emotional sensibility, body-awareness
- Elementary mathematics: calculus, cardinal numbers, comprehension of quantity
- Speech development

Every player will take some cards from other players, and you can't see that cards.

Then each player take turns to guess what cards they have.
ex. "Am I Smart?" "NO~~you are not!"or "Yes! you are"

The winner is the first person to guess all the cards.

User summary

Critter Commandos started as boardgame miniature rules (Critter Commandos) published by Crunchy Frog Enterprises/ Team Frog in 1989. It was a slapstick sci-fi game with "funny animals". Three years later, they released the Critter Commandos Compendium which included role-playing rules for the game, but also more races, weapons, a WH 40k conversion, and expanded vehicles rules.

boardgame.name: The Hive
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Hive are a menace to every form of life in the galaxy. Ever spreading, ever growing, the influence of the Hive is felt across a wide swath of space. One by one these creatures have infested life bearing worlds, ravaging them and leaving the ecology twisted and unrecognizable. On the very edges of the outer Fringe you can witness the evidence of their presence first hand as formerly verdant and thriving worlds are being eaten alive by the ravenous masses of Hive drones.

This book presents a GM with a major threat for use in a space faring science fiction campaign. Infinite Futures: The Hive contains a number of new creatures, complete with background information and plot hooks, for use with the Infinite Futures main rulebook.

boardgame.name: The DeMorteval Mausoleum
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The inscription above the door of this grand mausoleum reads 'The Noble Family of DeMorteval', and those that do not know the true story of the family may believe it's an accurate description of the family. But those that remember the truth of this family may tell a different story.

Need a quick map for an encounter?
A printable battlemap compatible with any RPG/Dungeon-Crawl game. Use as a standalone gameboard, or combine with any same-scale tileset.

Contents: A 20 x 20 map depicting a Gothic mausoleum set within a misty cemetery. Tombs and gravestones are covered in ivy, and stand beside a grand ornate Gothic structure. Within the sepulchre are 7 tombs of the DeMorteval Family. But what secrets does the Mausoleum hold? Is there something hidden beneath the family crest? Are the tombs actually empty? Are the DeMorteval's actually dead? Perfect for Halloween adventures, as well as modern horror, Victoriana and Cthulu adventures.

boardgame.name: The Horrors of Halfling Hollow
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This is a short encounter "location" that is systemless and scalable for about any level of PCs in any OSR-style game. The design is deliberately vague in several areas to make it easy to "tweak & toss" into your current campaign. Perfect for when the party goes "left" when you expected them to go "right", any GM/DM/Judge can easily drop this into the current campaign.

The idea behind this Tweak & Toss is that there is a small, almost hidden, community of Halflings out in the arid wasteland steppes between two kingdoms. It might be a great place for the party to use as a much-needed rest stop or as a staging post for underground forays. You players could come and go from this community many times without learning about one couple's dark "hobby". Grab your group's attention immediately or let this secret fester hidden in the background, the choice is yours.

It is intended to print this file two-sided and fold in half, zine-style. Just select "booklet printing" and make sure that you have duplex set up on the short edge.

This PDF download consists of eight pages of content (maps, village, NPCs, and basic set-up). There are a couple of hotlinks within the file taking you to some additional resources, one of which is the Patreon site where you can download better versions of the overview map if you so desire.
